bibl.title: Letter from James C. Reed to James E. Peabody, June 20, 1933

div1.p: James Reed writes that he regrets having missed Peabody's visit. He provides information about himself and his brothers.

div1.head: Letter from James C. Reed to James E. Peabody, June 20, 1933
div1.opener:
FROM JAMES E. PEABODY
(Letter from Walter Reed's oldest brother.)
811 South Main Street,
Blackstone, Virginia,
June 20, 1933.
Mr. James E. Peabody,
152 Hargard Street,
Newtonville, Mass.,
My dear Mr. Peabody:
div1.p:
My daughter and niece have told me of my great misfortune in not
being at home when you called to see them. They were charmed with your
visit. I have read with great pleasure and interest both the type-
written and printed matter you left them concerning my youngest brother,
Walter Reed. He was the youngest of four brothers, namely James Clayton
Thomas Walk, Christopher, and Walter. Three of these have passed away
to the great beyond. Walter was the first to go, then Christopher, then
Thomas Walk. I, James Clayton, the eldest, now 90 years of age, alone
remain.

With Walter and his work you were acquainted. Christopher was
Circuit Judge of Wichita, Kansas, for many years--said by many to be a
brilliant lawyer. Thomas W. was a merchant and farmer in Kansas. Thoug
not very successful in accumulating this world's goods, when he died
they spoke of him as “Honest Tom Reed.”

The least said about myself the better. But believing you will
be interested in Walter Reed's Brother, I will add a few lines more. At
the age of 18 I entered the Army of the Confedearte States and was a
Sergeant in a Battery of Light Artillery. I lost my left arm at Sharps-
burg, Maryland, September 17th., 1862. I returned to the Army and sur-
rendered with Lee at Appomattox April 9th., 1865.

I entered the Virginia Conference, M. E. Church, South, November
1868. Spent 53 years in active service. Retired at the age of 79.
This will be my 65th. year in the ministry. I am the oldest man and
minister in the Virginia Conference--ninety years of age.
